result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.descr: Demand for Discovery and Inspection - Prosecutor

records.addlTxt: State's Notice of Motion and Motion for Establishment of Discovery Timelines

2:19 PM (64-05) 22CF428 & 22CF430 Defendant April K Garcia in court.  Attorney Joshua Ryan-Polczinski in court for April K Garcia.  Plaintiff State of Wisconsin Samuel Berg in court. 
State called to the stand as a witness, Deputy Caleb Broege.
Caleb Broege duly sworn by the clerk and testified on direct examination by ADA Berg.
Witness has identified the defendant in court.
Exhibit #1 marked, identified and discussed in court.
Exhibit #1 offered and received by the court.
2:22PM - Cross examination by Atty Ryan.
2:25PM - 22CF430
State called to the stand as a witness Deputy David McMillan.
David McMillan duly sworn by the clerk and testified on direct examination by ADA Berg.
Exhibit #1 marked, identified and discussed. Exhibit #1 offered and received by the court.
Cross examination by Atty Ryan.
Evidence is closed.
State gives argument. Requesting Bound over.
Attorney Ryan requests probable cause not be found.
Victim not in court.
Court finds probable cause that a felony has been committed and that the defendant likely committed it and binds her over to stand trial on the charges on both files.

State requesting Arraignment date.

Adj.  2:29PM
Arraignment scheduled for September 15, 2022 at 01:15 pm.
